title: Duchess Meghan, Prince Harry visit South Africa's oldest mosque on royal tour
text:
Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan continued their South Africa tour Tuesday with a visit to a 225-year-old Cape Town mosque, where Meghan followed custom and draped a flowing headscarf over her long locks.

The Duke and Duchess of Sussex visited South Africa's oldest mosque, the Auwal Mosque, on Heritage Day, a South African holiday to celebrate the nation's culture and diversity.

Duchess Meghan of Sussex donned the customary headscarf to visit the Auwal Mosque with Prince Harry during day two of their royal tour of South Africa on Sept. 24, 2019 in Cape Town, South Africa. More

To visit the holy site, Meghan donned a cream headscarf and a long olive-green dress with short sleeves. She paired the look with beige flats and wore her hair down.

It's customary and good manners for women to cover their hair and dress modestly when they visit a mosque, just as it was long tradition for women to cover their hair when they entered Roman Catholic churches.

Harry opted for a light gray suit, a light blue shirt and brown belt and shoes.

The Auwal Mosque is the first, and therefore oldest, mosque in South Africa, and remains a symbol of the recognition of Islam and for the freedom of former slaves to worship as Muslims.

The couple's stop at the 225-year-old mosque included a viewing of the first known manuscript of the Quran in South Africa.

Authorities say it was written down from memory by an imam while he was imprisoned on nearby Robben Island during a period when slaves were not allowed to worship Islam.

The couple's popular Instagram account a short video clips of some of their activities on day 2 of the tour, including the visit to the mosque and their visit to the Bo-Kaap community with its colorfully painted houses.

At the mosque, they met with several religious leaders to discuss interfaith dialogue in the famously diverse city of Cape Town.

After they visited the mosque, the royal couple dropped in to the home of a local resident, Shamielah Samsodian and her family, who hosted them for tea at a table piled high with local delicacies.

In the evening, they attended a reception at the residence of the British High Commissioner where they met young leaders and influencers.

For the party, Meghan donned another dress, a sleeveless, pleated, striped long dress by Martin Grant.

The Duke and Duchess, along with their nearly 5-month-old baby, Archie, arrived in Cape Town, South Africa, Monday for the start of a 10-day tour of southern Africa, their first official foreign trip as a family.

The royal couple also stopped to greet people of the Bo-Kaap neighborhood during Day 2 of their visit.

Earlier Tuesday, Harry and Meghan went to Monwabisi Beach in Cape Town to visit the NGO "Waves for Change," a program that trains and supports local surfers to provide mental health services to young people.

They met "surf mentors" and participated in a group activity to promote positive thinking.

Meghan dressed down in black jeans, a white shirt and a jeans jacket. Harry wore gray pants and a button-up shirt.

Close-up pictures of Meghan's left hand showed she was not wearing her diamond engagement ring, reported to have cost anywhere from $130,000 to $350,000 at the time of her engagement in November 2017.

According to the Daily Mail and to Hello magazine, Meghan sought to be more informal and "low-key" during during the trip.

Separately, Harry boarded a speedy boat to travel to Seal Island in Kalk Bay, accompanied by Royal Marines and a Cape Town maritime police unit, to learn about the fight to prevent abalone poaching, one of South Africa’s most significant illegal wildlife trade concerns.

The Royal Marines (Harry is the honorary captain general) have been training Cape Town maritime police to help improve their boat-handling skills and operational effectiveness. Since the training, the maritime police have detained a number of abalone smugglers in the Cape Town area who were operating at night, Buckingham Palace said.
description: Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan continued their South Africa tour Tuesday with a visit to a mosque in Cape Town.
